article.headline: Gonzaga outshoots, outrebounds foe
article.story: MALIBU, Calif. (AP) -- Gonzaga (No. 17 ESPN/USA Today, No. 16 AP) completely dominated Pepperdine in its West Coast Conference opener, with one exception. The Bulldogs forced only three turnovers while committing 16. It hardly mattered. Cory Violette had 20 points and nine rebounds, and Blake Stepp scored 16 of his 19 points in the second half Thursday night to lead the Bulldogs to an 87-70 victory over the Waves. Gonzaga shot 28-of-47 (59.6 percent) including 10-of-17 from 3-point range and won the rebounding battle 44-25. "That was one of our goals coming in, to get a good glass deficit on them," Violette said. The Waves, meanwhile, shot 26-of-70 (37.1 percent) including 8-of-30 from beyond the arc. "It's a huge win, without a doubt," Violette said. "Every road win in conference is huge -- especially at Pepperdine." The Bulldogs will try to get another road victory Saturday night at Loyola Marymount, where they were upset 80-74 last season. "They didn't play, that puts us at a competitive disadvantage," Gonzaga coach Mark Few said. The Portland-Loyola Marymount game scheduled Thursday night was postponed until Monday because the airport in Portland was closed due to a snow and ice storm. The win was the fourth straight for the Bulldogs (11-2) while the Waves (5-11) lost their fifth in a row -- their longest losing streak since the 1996-97 season. "Somewhere in there, we're doing something right," Pepperdine coach Paul Westphal said, noting the differential in turnovers and shot attempts. "But they killed us on the boards. "They're very good. They shot really well, we shot very poorly." Gonzaga has won eight of the last nine games between the teams and has a 50-7 conference record since Few became its coach before the 1999-2000 season. "We had a good approach -- playing on the road, playing aggressive," Few said. Kyle Bankhead and Errol Knight added 10 points each for Gonzaga and Bankhead also had eight rebounds. "He's been solid all year," Few said of Bankhead. "In some ways, he's been our MVP. He's just rock solid. He's a tough, tough kid who does exactly what you want him to do." Ronny Turiaf was held to nine points and seven rebounds, but his teammates did more than enough. Glen McGowan led Pepperdine with 20 points and six rebounds. Shaun Davis added 16 points and six assists and Terrance Johnson scored 15 for the Waves, but shot 5-of-21. A 3-pointer by Johnson capped a 10-3 run by Pepperdine that cut Gonzaga's lead to 50-42 early in the second half. That was as close as the Waves would get. A three-point play by Violette finished an 11-4 spurt that featured two 3-pointers by Stepp, making it 68-52 with 8:41 remaining. The Bulldogs stretched their lead to 73-55 before Johnson made a pair of 3-pointers to move within 12 points with 5{ minutes left. But Stepp's 3-pointer triggered a 7-2 run that put the game out of reach. The Bulldogs, who led 40-27 at halftime, played their second game without starting forward Tony Skinner (broken right hand) and reserve center Richard Fox (injured right knee). Both are sidelined indefinitely.
